column4: Blue = Do not change; Green = free text

column1:
The Open Enzyme Collection consists of 81 genes for enzymes that are "workhorses" of molecular biology, including DNA polymerases, RNA polymerases, DNA ligases, reverse transcriptases and restriction enzymes. The enzymes are useful in both basic and applied fields as diverse as genomics, diagnostics, biodiversity, synthetic biology, DNA origami, immunology, biochemistry and more.

The foundational technologies enabled by this collection of include polymerase chain reaction (PCR), cloning, isothermal amplification, reverse transcription of RNA into DNA, and dNTP synthesis. Additionally, the Open Enzyme collection contains enzyme genes for fixing damaged and degraded DNA prior to amplification, enzymes for cutting protein sequences to remove unwanted parts, and DNA-binding proteins that can be fused with other enzymes to improve functionality.

The Open Bioeconomy Lab designed and codon-optimized the Open Enzymes parts for expression in Escherichia coli bacteria. All enzymes are obtained from expired patents or for various reasons are not encumbered by patent rights. (copied directly from https://stanford.freegenes.org/collections/open-genes/products/openenzyme#description)

column3: High consitutive promoter from Anderson library
Designed with a high GC content for higher melting points
column5: plasmid used to test promoter strength in  E coli

column2: Blue text column headers are optional
Click on column headers for more information as to what to put into the column

column1: Short and human friendly name for the part, e.g., "GFP Reporter"
column2: This is the role of the part according to the sequence ontology (see Ontology tab for full list). Select from the drop down menu or type have it validated.
column3: Comments about design decisions. E.g. GC content or restriction sites removed
column4: If no changes were made use Direct, otherwise say changes that were made (can choose for drop down menu)
column5: A description of how the part is meant to function and any information about the part that is not to do with how it was designed.
column6: Where is the information about this part coming from? Provide a tag and e.g. AG for an Addgene plasmid. Tags found in the Source Sheet
column7: Where is the information about this part coming from? Provide a te.g. 87906 for an Addgene plasmid. This is interpreted together with the column to the left
column8: Where is the genetic information coming from, e.g. gene taken from Aequorea victoria if available add in strain name too. This should match the scientific name for the txid in the next column
column9: Where will the part be used, e.g. construct for use in Escherichia coli 98NK2. Where available include the strain name. This should match the scientific name for the txid in the next column
column10: True if this is a final product to be produced, false if this is an intermediate stage being specified for compactness
column11: Whether or not the part is circular. Select TRUE (circular) or FALSE (linear).
column12: Automatically calculated length of the sequence pasted to the right. Use this column for checking there are no paste errors.
column13: The series of ATGCs that make up the part. Spaces can be used within the sequence but no other characters.
